'''Nelly Adam Malik''' (née '''Ilyas''';<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://books.google.co.id/books?id=WwYiAAAAMAAJ&q=Nelly+Ilyas+adam+malik&dq=Nelly+Ilyas+adam+malik&hl=id&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjg-4uph472AhUFwjgGHVIIDIIQ6AF6BAgHEAM|title=Srikandi: sejumlah wanita Indonesia berprestasi|date=27 Mar 1991|publisher=Ciptawidya Swara|access-date=27 March 2025|via=Google Books}}</ref> 15 May 1925 – 25 March 2007) was the wife of the third vice president of Indonesia, [[Adam Malik]]. She served as the [[Second Lady of Indonesia]] from 1978 to 1983.

An active figure in social and community organizations, Nelly was known for her concern regarding social welfare issues. For her service to the nation, the government of Indonesia awarded her the [[Star of Mahaputera|Star of Mahaputera Adipradana]] on 17 August 1982.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Daftar WNI yang Mendapat Tanda Kehormatan Bintang Mahaputera tahun 1959 s.d. 2003|url=https://cdn.setneg.go.id/_multimedia/document/20180910/41462-Bintang_Mahaputera_tahun_1959-2003.pdf|website=Sekretariat Negara Republik Indonesia|access-date=2021-01-20}}</ref>

== Early life ==
[[File:Adam Malik dan istri.jpg|thumb|left|Nelly Adam Malik with her husband, [[Adam Malik]]]]
Nelly was the second daughter of Datuk Ilyas (styled Rajo Mara) and Siti Zuleiha, who were [[Minangkabau people|Minangkabau]] migrants from [[West Sumatra]].<ref name=ti>[http://www.tokohindonesia.com/biografi/article/286-direktori/1893-peduli-masalah-sosial "Profil Nelly Adam Malik"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121125083037/http://www.tokohindonesia.com/biografi/article/286-direktori/1893-peduli-masalah-sosial |date=2012-11-25 }} Tokoh Indonesia. Accessed 8 May 2013.</ref> During her childhood, she was raised by a Dutch foster family, who gave her the name Nelly.

She attended the [[Hollandsch-Inlandsche School]] (HIS), graduating in 1937, followed by the [[MULO]] and the "NISVO" (Nederlandsch-Indische Sociale Vrouwen-Organisatie) teachers' school for domestic science from 1938 to 1940. She also took several English language courses.<ref name=dpr1971>{{Cite web|url=https://books.google.co.id/books?id=VODlHHq4FukC&pg=PA340|title=Riwayat hidup anggota-anggota Majelis Permusyawaratan Rakyat hasil pemilihan umum 1971|first=Indonesia Lembaga Pemilihan|last=Umum|date=27 Mar 1973|publisher=Lembaga Pemilihan Umum|access-date=27 March 2025|via=Google Books}}</ref>

== Career and marriage ==
In 1942, Nelly married Adam Malik while he was a journalist and a co-founder of the [[Antara (news agency)|Antara News Agency]]. Nelly, then 17 years old, worked as an employee at the newly established agency. She later became active in politics, supporting her husband's role in the Indonesian independence movement.

Before her husband's tenure as vice president, Nelly was an elected politician in her own right. She served as a member of the [[People's Representative Council]] (DPR-RI) representing the [[Golkar]] party from 1971 to 1982. The couple had five children: Otto Malik, Antarini Malik, Ilham Malik, Imron Malik, and Budisita Malik.<ref name=ti/>

Throughout her career, she held several leadership positions in social and political organizations:
* Founded a kindergarten in [[Yogyakarta]] (1949).
* General Chairperson of the Indonesia-Soviet Union Women's Association while her husband was [[List of ambassadors of Indonesia to Russia|Ambassador to the Soviet Union]].
* General Chairperson of the Trade Department Family Association (1964).
* Member of the leadership council of the [[Murba Party]]'s women's wing (1964).
* After the dissolution of Murba in 1965, she joined Golkar and served as the General Chairperson of ''Wanita Satya Praja''.
* Coordinator of the Foreign Affairs Department Women's Organization (1966).
* Coordinator of Golkar's Women's Coordination body (1972).<ref name=dpr1971/>

== Death ==
[[File:Nelly Adam Malik-TMPNU Kalibata 2.jpg|thumb|Headstone of Nelly Adam Malik at Kalibata Heroes Cemetery]]
Nelly Adam Malik died at the MMC Hospital in Kuningan, Jakarta, on 25 March 2007, following a [[stroke]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.detik.com/berita/d-758372/istri-adam-malik-tutup-usia|title=Istri Adam Malik Tutup Usia|website=detiknews|access-date=28 March 2025}}</ref> She was buried with military honors at the [[Kalibata Heroes Cemetery]] in Jakarta.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.antaranews.com/berita/57035/jenazah-nelly-adam-malik-akan-dimakamkan-di-tmp-kalibata|title=Jenazah Nelly Adam Malik Akan Dimakamkan di TMP Kalibata|date=26 March 2007|website=Antara News|access-date=28 March 2025}}</ref>

'''Nelly Adam Malik''' (née '''Ilyas''';<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://books.google.co.id/books?id=WwYiAAAAMAAJ&q=Nelly+Ilyas+adam+malik&dq=Nelly+Ilyas+adam+malik&hl=id&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjg-4uph472AhUFwjgGHVIIDIIQ6AF6BAgHEAM|title=Srikandi: sejumlah wanita Indonesia berprestasi|date=27 Mar 1991|publisher=Ciptawidya Swara|access-date=27 March 2025|via=Google Books}}</ref> 15 May 1925 – 25 March 2007) was the wife of the third vice president of Indonesia, [[Adam Malik]]. She served as the [[Second Lady of Indonesia]] from 1978 to 1983.

An active figure in social and community organizations, Nelly was known for her concern regarding social welfare issues. For her service to the nation, the government of Indonesia awarded her the [[Star of Mahaputera|Star of Mahaputera Adipradana]] on 17 August 1982.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Daftar WNI yang Mendapat Tanda Kehormatan Bintang Mahaputera tahun 1959 s.d. 2003|url=https://cdn.setneg.go.id/_multimedia/document/20180910/41462-Bintang_Mahaputera_tahun_1959-2003.pdf|website=Sekretariat Negara Republik Indonesia|access-date=2021-01-20}}</ref>

Accessed 8 May 2013.</ref> During her childhood, she was raised by a Dutch foster family, who gave her the name Nelly.

She attended the [[Hollandsch-Inlandsche School]] (HIS), graduating in 1937, followed by the [[MULO]] and the "NISVO" (Nederlandsch-Indische Sociale Vrouwen-Organisatie) teachers' school for domestic science from 1938 to 1940. '''Nelly Adam Malik''' (née '''Ilyas''';<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://books.google.co.id/books?id=WwYiAAAAMAAJ&q=Nelly+Ilyas+adam+malik&dq=Nelly+Ilyas+adam+malik&hl=id&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjg-4uph472AhUFwjgGHVIIDIIQ6AF6BAgHEAM|title=Srikandi: sejumlah wanita Indonesia berprestasi|date=27 Mar 1991|publisher=Ciptawidya Swara|access-date=27 March 2025|via=Google Books}}</ref> 15 May 1925 – 25 March 2007) was the wife of the third vice president of Indonesia, [[Adam Malik]]. She served as the [[Second Lady of Indonesia]] from 1978 to 1983.

An active figure in social and community organizations, Nelly was known for her concern regarding social welfare issues. For her service to the nation, the government of Indonesia awarded her the [[Star of Mahaputera|Star of Mahaputera Adipradana]] on 17 August 1982.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Daftar WNI yang Mendapat Tanda Kehormatan Bintang Mahaputera tahun 1959 s.d. 2003|url=https://cdn.setneg.go.id/_multimedia/document/20180910/41462-Bintang_Mahaputera_tahun_1959-2003.pdf|website=Sekretariat Negara Republik Indonesia|access-date=2021-01-20}}</ref>

== Early life ==
[[File:Adam Malik dan istri.jpg|thumb|left|Nelly Adam Malik with her husband, [[Adam Malik]]]]
Nelly was the second daughter of Datuk Ilyas (styled Rajo Mara) and Siti Zuleiha, who were [[Minangkabau people|Minangkabau]] migrants from [[West Sumatra]].<ref name=ti>[http://www.tokohindonesia.com/biografi/article/286-direktori/1893-peduli-masalah-sosial "Profil Nelly Adam Malik"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121125083037/http://www.tokohindonesia.com/biografi/article/286-direktori/1893-peduli-masalah-sosial |date=2012-11-25 }} Tokoh Indonesia. Accessed 8 May 2013.</ref> During her childhood, she was raised by a Dutch foster family, who gave her the name Nelly.

She attended the [[Hollandsch-Inlandsche School]] (HIS), graduating in 1937, followed by the [[MULO]] and the "NISVO" (Nederlandsch-Indische Sociale Vrouwen-Organisatie) teachers' school for domestic science from 1938 to 1940. She also took several English language courses.<ref name=dpr1971>{{Cite web|url=https://books.google.co.id/books?id=VODlHHq4FukC&pg=PA340|title=Riwayat hidup anggota-anggota Majelis Permusyawaratan Rakyat hasil pemilihan umum 1971|first=Indonesia Lembaga Pemilihan|last=Umum|date=27 Mar 1973|publisher=Lembaga Pemilihan Umum|access-date=27 March 2025|via=Google Books}}</ref>

== Career and marriage ==
In 1942, Nelly married Adam Malik while he was a journalist and a co-founder of the [[Antara (news agency)|Antara News Agency]]. Nelly, then 17 years old, worked as an employee at the newly established agency. She later became active in politics, supporting her husband's role in the Indonesian independence movement.

Before her husband's tenure as vice president, Nelly was an elected politician in her own right. She served as a member of the [[People's Representative Council]] (DPR-RI) representing the [[Golkar]] party from 1971 to 1982. The couple had five children: Otto Malik, Antarini Malik, Ilham Malik, Imron Malik, and Budisita Malik.<ref name=ti/>

Throughout her career, she held several leadership positions in social and political organizations:
* Founded a kindergarten in [[Yogyakarta]] (1949).
* General Chairperson of the Indonesia-Soviet Union Women's Association while her husband was [[List of ambassadors of Indonesia to Russia|Ambassador to the Soviet Union]].
* General Chairperson of the Trade Department Family Association (1964).
* Member of the leadership council of the [[Murba Party]]'s women's wing (1964).
* After the dissolution of Murba in 1965, she joined Golkar and served as the General Chairperson of ''Wanita Satya Praja''.
* Coordinator of the Foreign Affairs Department Women's Organization (1966).
* Coordinator of Golkar's Women's Coordination body (1972).<ref name=dpr1971/>

== Death ==
[[File:Nelly Adam Malik-TMPNU Kalibata 2.jpg|thumb|Headstone of Nelly Adam Malik at Kalibata Heroes Cemetery]]
Nelly Adam Malik died at the MMC Hospital in Kuningan, Jakarta, on 25 March 2007, following a [[stroke]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.detik.com/berita/d-758372/istri-adam-malik-tutup-usia|title=Istri Adam Malik Tutup Usia|website=detiknews|access-date=28 March 2025}}</ref> She was buried with military honors at the [[Kalibata Heroes Cemetery]] in Jakarta.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.antaranews.com/berita/57035/jenazah-nelly-adam-malik-akan-dimakamkan-di-tmp-kalibata|title=Jenazah Nelly Adam Malik Akan Dimakamkan di TMP Kalibata|date=26 March 2007|website=Antara News|access-date=28 March 2025}}</ref>

{{main|Chip 'n Dale: Rescue Rangers (TV series)}}
{{main|Chip 'n Dale: Rescue Rangers (TV series)}}

In 1989, Chip and Dale became the title characters in a new animated television series, ''[[Chip 'n Dale: Rescue Rangers (TV series)|Chip 'n Dale: Rescue Rangers]]'', in which they formed a [[Private investigator|detective]] agency with new characters created for the show: female mouse inventor Gadget Hackwrench, muscular adventuring Australian mouse Monterey Jack and Zipper the fly. While in the original shorts, the duo is frequent troublemakers who are concerned only with themselves, in ''Rescue Rangers'', they are crime fighters who help the less fortunate.<ref>{{cite news|title= Boom! and Ian Brill Retrieve Chip 'n Dale rescue rangers |work=[[Newsarama]]|url= http://www.newsarama.com/comics/rescue-rangers-boom-studios-100903.html|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20100907075953/http://www.newsarama.com/comics/rescue-rangers-boom-studios-100903.html|url-status= dead|archive-date= September 7, 2010|access-date=2011-01-10}}</ref>

The characters have a [[French Americans|French-American]] animated series called ''Chip 'n' Dale: Park Life'', which was released on [[Disney+]] on July 28, 2021,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://deadline.com/2021/02/disney-plus-premiere-dates-turner-and-hooch-mysterious-benedict-society-high-school-musical-the-musical-series-chip-n-dale-park-life-1234699824/|title=Disney+ Sets Premiere Dates, First Images For 'Turner & Hooch', 'Mysterious Benedict Society', 'Chip 'N' Dale: Park Life' & 'High School Musical: The Series'|first=Erik|last=Peterson|work=Deadline|date=February 24, 2021|access-date=February 24, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Paz |first=Maggie Dela |date=June 16, 2021 |title=Opening Title Sequence for Disney+'s Chip 'n' Dale: Park Life Revealed |url=https://www.comingsoon.net/tv/trailers/1178592-opening-title-disney-plus-chip-n-dale-park-life |newspaper=Comingsoon.net}}</ref> which was co-produced by [[The Walt Disney Company France]] and [[Xilam Animation]]. Unlike other iterations of the characters, the series is non-verbal, similarly to other shows produced by Xilam.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.animationmagazine.net/tv/first-look-disney-unveils-pics-from-new-chip-n-dale-series-at-annecy/|title=First Look : Disney+ Unveils Pics from New 'Chip 'n' Dale' Series at Annecy|first=Ramin|last=Zahed|work=Animation Magazine|date=June 11, 2019|access-date=June 12, 2019}}</ref> The series portrays Chip and Dale's adventures living in a park where they often interact with Clarice, Donald Duck, Pluto, and other mostly [[Duckburg]]-centric Disney characters. The chipmunks are portrayed in only semi-humanized form, much as in late-1940s cartoon shorts.

Life

← Previous revision Revision as of 09:00, 7 February 2026
Line 43: Line 43:
By age 17, he and his older brother James were working in Birmingham when the [[Blitzkrieg|German blitz]] of [[World War II]] began. There, they both joined a Works Fire Service and would be despatched in both Birmingham and nearby Coventry.<ref>{{Cite news |date=10 February 1999 |title=Public park to be named after Newry's legendary firefighter |work=The Newry Democrat}}</ref> two Uncles of Jackie’s wife, Robert Campbell and Mickey Linney being inspiration. Jackie would earn the Defence medal for this contribution.
By age 17, he and his older brother James were working in Birmingham when the [[Blitzkrieg|German blitz]] of [[World War II]] began. There, they both joined a Works Fire Service and would be despatched in both Birmingham and nearby Coventry.<ref>{{Cite news |date=10 February 1999 |title=Public park to be named after Newry's legendary firefighter |work=The Newry Democrat}}</ref> two Uncles of Jackie’s wife, Robert Campbell and Mickey Linney being inspiration. Jackie would earn the Defence medal for this contribution.


Upon returning to Northern Ireland, McClelland joined Auxiliary Fire Serve which was later rebranded the[[National Fire Service]]. Stationed at Central Fire Station on Chichester Street in Belfast until the National Fire Service was disbanded in 1948.
Upon returning to Northern Ireland, McClelland joined Auxiliary Fire Serve which was later rebranded the [[National Fire Service]]. Stationed at Central Fire Station on Chichester Street in Belfast until the National Fire Service was disbanded in 1948.


Returning to his hometown, he joined the Newry Depot reuniting with his brother. The Newry depot was now under the control of the Northern Ireland Fire Authority. Some of his early mentors included Tommy Lyons and Christy Hughes, along with another legendary firefighting figure [[James Heather (firefighter)|Jimmy Heather]]. His brother fell from a ladder in 1952 whilst labouring and would later serve under reduced hours for the brigade before leaving the organisation in 1954 to migrate to America. Jimmy died 3 years later.

Jimmy died 3 years later.

← Previous revision Revision as of 09:00, 7 February 2026
Line 38: Line 38:
In 1942 the nearby [[Mother church|matrice]] parish [[Stella Maris Church, Sliema|Church of Stella Maris]] was severely damaged by an aerial raid during [[World War II]], and the Galea family opened their house as an alternative place for worship during and after the war, until the parish church opened to the public again.<ref name=alfie/><ref>{{cite journal|journal=Tas-Sliema: Lehen Il-Kunsill Tieghek|last=Vassallo|first=John N.|date=June 2017|title=Feast of the Ascension: 14th May 1942|url=http://sliemalocalcouncil.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/Sliema-Magzine-2007-vol-5-3.pdf|volume=5|issue=3|pages=26–27}}{{dead link|date=March 2025|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
In 1942 the nearby [[Mother church|matrice]] parish [[Stella Maris Church, Sliema|Church of Stella Maris]] was severely damaged by an aerial raid during [[World War II]], and the Galea family opened their house as an alternative place for worship during and after the war, until the parish church opened to the public again.<ref name=alfie/><ref>{{cite journal|journal=Tas-Sliema: Lehen Il-Kunsill Tieghek|last=Vassallo|first=John N.|date=June 2017|title=Feast of the Ascension: 14th May 1942|url=http://sliemalocalcouncil.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/Sliema-Magzine-2007-vol-5-3.pdf|volume=5|issue=3|pages=26–27}}{{dead link|date=March 2025|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>


The daughter of Galea, Mary Xavier, became a Catholic nun and at this point the family donated the Villa to the ''White Sister'', the same Catholic organization which Mary joined.<ref name=alfie/><ref name="zammit"/><ref>{{cite news|last=Vella|first=Charles|date=1 September 2013|title=Rare distinction for two Maltese nuns|url=https://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20130901/letters/Rare-distinction-for-two-Maltese-nuns.484326|work=Times of Malta|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170321082825/https://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20130901/letters/Rare-distinction-for-two-Maltese-nuns.484326|archive-date=21 March 2017}}</ref> The short-lived religious organization was founded in 1957, when the house was transferred from the family to the church, and became defunct by 1960.<ref name="zammit">{{cite journal|last=Zammit|first=Winston L.|date=December 2014|title=Djar f'Tas-Sliema: Fatima House (Betharram)|url=http://sliemalocalcouncil.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/Magazine-Issue-December-2014-FINAL-Small.pdf|publisher=Sliema Local Council|page=28}}{{dead link|date=March 2025|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
The daughter of Galea, Mary Xavier, became a Catholic nun and at this point the family donated the Villa to the ''White Sister'', the same Catholic organization which Mary joined.<ref name=alfie/><ref name="zammit"/><ref>{{cite news|last=Vella|first=Charles|date=1 September 2013|title=Rare distinction for two Maltese nuns|url=https://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20130901/letters/Rare-distinction-for-two-Maltese-nuns.484326|work=Times of Malta|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170321082825/https://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20130901/letters/Rare-distinction-for-two-Maltese-nuns.484326|archive-date=21 March 2017}}</ref> The short-lived religious organization was founded in 1957, when the house was transferred from the family to the church, and became defunct by 1960.<ref name="zammit">{{cite journal|last=Zammit|first=Winston L.|date=December 2014|title=Djar f'Tas-Sliema: Fatima House (Betharram)|url=http://sliemalocalcouncil.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/Magazine-Issue-December-2014-FINAL-Small.pdf|journal=Sliema Local Council|page=28}}{{dead link|date=March 2025|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>


The donation of the property received a prominent coverage by the [[Times of Malta]] on 19 September 1957, when passed to the sisters, and was described as a stately home due to being one of the largest residences in Sliema.<ref name="zammit"/> The main scope of donating the property was to serve as an ideal place for newly ordained sisters to further their studies for their vocation and as a residence.<ref name="zammit"/> The family received praise by being named for their gesture.<ref name="zammit"/> The newspaper said that:<ref name="zammit"/>

Circassian languages

← Previous revision Revision as of 09:00, 7 February 2026
Line 56: Line 56:


==== Circassian languages ====
==== Circassian languages ====
Historically in [[Circassians|Circassian]] society, the Quran was read in Arabic by a mullah, who would then translate and explain the text into the Circassian language for the congregation.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Tornau |first=Fedor Fedorovich |url=https://books.google.com.tr/books/about/%D0%92%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%B7%D1%81.html?id=GvVgzQEACAAJ&redir_esc=y |title=Воспоминания кавказского офицера |date=1994 |publisher=TOO "Adzhʹpa" |language=ru}}</ref>
*The [[Adyghe language|Adyghe]] translation of the Quran, "Meanings of the Quranic Verses", was prepared by [[Iskhak Mashbash]] and Phimaf Koshbay. Faiz Autle and Daut Tlebzu served as Arabic language consultants.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Кощбэе |first=Пщымаф |title=КъурIан Iаятэхэм ямэхьанэхэр |last2=МэщбэшIэ |first2=Исхьакъ |last3=Аулъэ |first3=Фаиз |last4=ЛIыбзыу |first4=Даут |language=ady|trans-title=Meanings of the Quranic Verses}}</ref>
*The [[Adyghe language|Adyghe]] translation of the Quran, "Meanings of the Quranic Verses", was prepared by [[Iskhak Mashbash]] and Phimaf Koshbay. Faiz Autle and Daut Tlebzu served as Arabic language consultants.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Кощбэе |first=Пщымаф |title=КъурIан Iаятэхэм ямэхьанэхэр |last2=МэщбэшIэ |first2=Исхьакъ |last3=Аулъэ |first3=Фаиз |last4=ЛIыбзыу |first4=Даут |language=ady|trans-title=Meanings of the Quranic Verses}}</ref>
*The [[Kabardian language|Kabardian]] translation of the Quran, "The Quran and the Meanings of the Quranic Verses in Circassian (Kabardian)", was prepared by Mukhamed Khuazh, Mustafa Boliy and Zaur Nalo.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Хъуажь |first=Мухьэмэд |title=КъурIэнымрэ КъурIэным и Iэятхэм я мыгIэнэмрэ адыгэбзэкIэ (къэбердей) |last2=Болий |first2=Мустафа |last3=Нало |first3=Заур |language=kbr |trans-title=The Quran and the Meanings of the Quranic Verses in Circassian (Kabardian)|url=https://circassianstudies.org/kutuphane/къурiэнымрэ-къурiэным-и-iэятхэм-я-мыгiэн/}}</ref>

← Previous revision Revision as of 09:00, 7 February 2026
Line 38: Line 38:
In 1942 the nearby [[Mother church|matrice]] parish [[Stella Maris Church, Sliema|Church of Stella Maris]] was severely damaged by an aerial raid during [[World War II]], and the Galea family opened their house as an alternative place for worship during and after the war, until the parish church opened to the public again.<ref name=alfie/><ref>{{cite journal|journal=Tas-Sliema: Lehen Il-Kunsill Tieghek|last=Vassallo|first=John N.|date=June 2017|title=Feast of the Ascension: 14th May 1942|url=http://sliemalocalcouncil.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/Sliema-Magzine-2007-vol-5-3.pdf|volume=5|issue=3|pages=26–27}}{{dead link|date=March 2025|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
In 1942 the nearby [[Mother church|matrice]] parish [[Stella Maris Church, Sliema|Church of Stella Maris]] was severely damaged by an aerial raid during [[World War II]], and the Galea family opened their house as an alternative place for worship during and after the war, until the parish church opened to the public again.<ref name=alfie/><ref>{{cite journal|journal=Tas-Sliema: Lehen Il-Kunsill Tieghek|last=Vassallo|first=John N.|date=June 2017|title=Feast of the Ascension: 14th May 1942|url=http://sliemalocalcouncil.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/Sliema-Magzine-2007-vol-5-3.pdf|volume=5|issue=3|pages=26–27}}{{dead link|date=March 2025|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>


The daughter of Galea, Mary Xavier, became a Catholic nun and at this point the family donated the Villa to the ''White Sister'', the same Catholic organization which Mary joined.<ref name=alfie/><ref name="zammit"/><ref>{{cite news|last=Vella|first=Charles|date=1 September 2013|title=Rare distinction for two Maltese nuns|url=https://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20130901/letters/Rare-distinction-for-two-Maltese-nuns.484326|work=Times of Malta|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170321082825/https://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20130901/letters/Rare-distinction-for-two-Maltese-nuns.484326|archive-date=21 March 2017}}</ref> The short-lived religious organization was founded in 1957, when the house was transferred from the family to the church, and became defunct by 1960.<ref name="zammit">{{cite journal|last=Zammit|first=Winston L.|date=December 2014|title=Djar f'Tas-Sliema: Fatima House (Betharram)|url=http://sliemalocalcouncil.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/Magazine-Issue-December-2014-FINAL-Small.pdf|publisher=Sliema Local Council|page=28}}{{dead link|date=March 2025|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
The daughter of Galea, Mary Xavier, became a Catholic nun and at this point the family donated the Villa to the ''White Sister'', the same Catholic organization which Mary joined.<ref name=alfie/><ref name="zammit"/><ref>{{cite news|last=Vella|first=Charles|date=1 September 2013|title=Rare distinction for two Maltese nuns|url=https://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20130901/letters/Rare-distinction-for-two-Maltese-nuns.484326|work=Times of Malta|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170321082825/https://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20130901/letters/Rare-distinction-for-two-Maltese-nuns.484326|archive-date=21 March 2017}}</ref> The short-lived religious organization was founded in 1957, when the house was transferred from the family to the church, and became defunct by 1960.<ref name="zammit">{{cite journal|last=Zammit|first=Winston L.|date=December 2014|title=Djar f'Tas-Sliema: Fatima House (Betharram)|url=http://sliemalocalcouncil.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/Magazine-Issue-December-2014-FINAL-Small.pdf|journal=Sliema Local Council|page=28}}{{dead link|date=March 2025|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>


The donation of the property received a prominent coverage by the [[Times of Malta]] on 19 September 1957, when passed to the sisters, and was described as a stately home due to being one of the largest residences in Sliema.<ref name="zammit"/> The main scope of donating the property was to serve as an ideal place for newly ordained sisters to further their studies for their vocation and as a residence.<ref name="zammit"/> The family received praise by being named for their gesture.<ref name="zammit"/> The newspaper said that:<ref name="zammit"/>

'''Bonli''' is a prominent town and a [[Tehsils of India|tehsil]] headquarters in the [[Sawai Madhopur district]] of the Indian state of [[Rajasthan]]. Located in the eastern part of the state, it serves as a significant administrative and commercial hub for the surrounding rural areas.
'''Bonli''' is a prominent town and a [[Tehsils of India|tehsil]] headquarters in the [[Sawai Madhopur district]] of the Indian state of [[Rajasthan]]. Located in the eastern part of the state, it serves as a significant administrative and commercial hub for the surrounding rural areas.


== Administration and Politics ==
== Administration and politics ==
Bonli is a Tehsil and Panchayat Samiti Headquarter. Administratively, it falls under the Sawai Madhopur district.
Bonli is a Tehsil and Panchayat Samiti Headquarter. Administratively, it falls under the Sawai Madhopur district.


Line 61: Line 61:
The primary languages spoken are [[Hindi]] and the local [[Dhundhari language|Dhundhari]] dialect.
The primary languages spoken are [[Hindi]] and the local [[Dhundhari language|Dhundhari]] dialect.


== Religious and Cultural Significance ==
== Religious and cultural significance ==
Bonli is known for its local temples and traditional Rajasthani culture.
Bonli is known for its local temples and traditional Rajasthani culture.


Line 68: Line 68:
'''Festivals:''' Like most of Rajasthan, festivals such as [[Diwali]], [[Holi]], [[Makar Sankranti]], and [[Gangaur]] are celebrated with great fervor.
'''Festivals:''' Like most of Rajasthan, festivals such as [[Diwali]], [[Holi]], [[Makar Sankranti]], and [[Gangaur]] are celebrated with great fervor.


== Infrastructure and Healthcare ==
== Infrastructure and healthcare ==
The town serves as a medical and educational hub for the surrounding villages.
The town serves as a medical and educational hub for the surrounding villages.
